sources.text: p. 378. 1823, Hannah Yarnall, a minister, member of Byberry Monthly Meeting, deceased 2nd of the 7th month last, in the 58th year of her age.

sources.text: vol. 1, p. 191. Hannah Haines; b. 2 mo. 26, 1765; d. 7 mo. 2, 1822; daughter of Edmond Haines (son of Abram Haines) and Elizabeth Warrington (dau. of Henry and Elizabeth (Bishop) Warrington); married 1st Joseph Thornton (1761-1790); mother of James Thornton (1795-); married 2nd Peter Yarnall (1754-1798); was a minister in the Society of Friends; traveled to Canada in 1803.
sources.citation: Haines, John Wesley, Richard Haines and his descendants, 1966

biogHists.text:
Hannah Haines Thornton (1765-1822), daughter of Edmund and Elizabeth Haines, was the widow of Joseph Thornton, a Quaker minister of Byberry Monthly Meeting. Joseph was the son of James Thornton (1751-1794), also a minister, and Mary Knight. The family resided on a large property in Byberry, purchased in 1752. Hannah Haines and Joseph Thornton were married in 1783 at Evesham Monthly Meeting, New Jersey, and they had three sons. Joseph Thornton and two sons died by 1790. Hannah was an Elder and then acknowledged as a minister by Byberry Monthly Meeting. In 1797, she married fellow widower Peter Yarnall and assumed responsibility for the children of his first marriage. Peter Yarnall and Hannah Thornton Yarnall had one child, Hannah (1797-1876), and the family lived on the homestead of James Thornton in Byberry. Peter Yarnall died 1798, 2 month, 20. Hannah Haines Yarnall travelled widely in the ministry and died month 2, 1822.

From the description of the Richardson-Yarnall family papers, 1722-1962. (Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College). http://archives.tricolib.brynmawr.edu/resources/5187rich

relations.note: Hannah Haines Yarnall was the daughter of Elizabeth Warrington Haines, sister of Hannah Warrington Buzby.
Hannah Haines Yarnall was the daughter of Elizabeth Warrington Haines, sister of Joseph Buzby's wife Hannah Warrington.

relations.content: Byberry Monthly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends
relations.note: Hannah Haines Thornton Yarnall was a minister of Byberry Monthly Meeting.
Hannah Haines Yarnall was the step-daughter of Enoch Evans, who married Hannah's mother Elizabeth Warrington after the death of Hannah's father Edmund Haines in 1766.
Hannah Haines Yarnall was the daughter of Elizabeth Warrington Haines, sister of Esther Warrington Hunt.
Hannah Haines Yarnall was the daughter of Elizabeth Warrington Haines, sister of John Hunt's wife Esther Warrington.
Hannah Haines Yarnall was the daughter of Elizabeth Warrington Haines, sister of William Rogers's first wife Sarah Warrington.
Hannah Haines's first husband was Joseph Thornton, son of James Thornton, Sr.
Hannah Haines's first husband was Joseph Thornton, brother of James Thornton, Jr.
Hannah Haines Yarnall was the daughter of Elizabeth Warrington Haines, sister of Aaron Wills's wife Rachel Warrington.
Hannah Haines Thornton Yarnall married Peter Yarnall, son of Mordecai Yarnall.

resource.title: Richardson-Yarnall family papers,1722-1962
resource.abstract: The collection contains personal papers, primarily correspondence, of members of the Richardson and Yarnall families, Pennsylvania Quakers who emigrated to America in the 1680s. The families were united by the marriage in 1816 of Nathaniel Richardson and Hannah Yarnall of Byberry. Of special significance are the diaries of Quaker ministers Peter Yarnall (1754-1798) and his second wife, Hannah Haines Thornton Yarnall (1765-1822) and their correspondence with family and fellow ministers. The papers reflect the daily life and concerns of members of two prominent families in southeastern Pennsylvania from the 18th through much of the 20th centuries.

nameEntries.original: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

resource.title: John Hunt papers, 1770-1828.
resource.abstract: John Hunt kept a diary for more than 40 years, recording Quaker concerns and daily events. This collections consists primarily of the manuscript journal, 1770-1800; fragments of 1805, 1806 & 1808; and 1814-1824. Of particular interest are the visits of prominent Quakers, including Elias Hicks and Jonathan Evans. There is also an account book, some correspondence received, and other miscellaneous materials. Correspondents include Ann R. Matlack, Asa Matlack, Elizabeth A. Lippincott, John Cox, Joseph Foulke, and Josiah Roberts.

nameEntries.original: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

resource.title: Roberts-Hunt family papers, 1677-1829.
resource.abstract: This collection includes papers relating to Rachel H. Roberts and her family. Included is correspondence between Esther Hunt Collins and her first husband, Joshua Hunt, his brother John, her children Elisha, Caleb and Rachel, her second husband, John Collins, and Hannah Yarnall. Also included is correspondence between Rachel H. Roberts and her husband, David. The collection includes genealogical information on the Roberts, Hooton, and other related families, along with wills and account books of Joseph and Susanna Roberts. Letters relate family news, impressions of Redstone Monthly Meeting of Friends, and discussions of Quaker discipline.
